elements.content: We demonstrate that the conformation, packing mode, and blue fluorescence of a soft piezofluorochromic compound can be preserved by structurally fixing it into a solid calcium metal–organic framework (Ca-MOF, LIFM-40), which can survive pressures up to 8 MPa. DFT calculations have been combined with experimental results to indicate that the ligands adopting a specific conformation and packing without π···π interactions are the reasons for its rigidified blue emission.
elements.clean_text: We demonstrate that the conformation, packing mode, and blue fluorescence of a soft piezofluorochromic compound can be preserved by structurally fixing it into a solid calcium metal-organic framework (Ca-MOF, LIFM-40), which can survive pressures up to 8 MPa. DFT calculations have been combined with experimental results to indicate that the ligands adopting a specific conformation and packing without π⋅⋅⋅π interactions are the reasons for its rigidified blue emission.

elements.content: The conformation, packing mode, and blue fluorescence of a soft piezofluorochromic compound can be preserved by structurally fixing it into a solid calcium metal−organic framework (Ca-MOF, LIFM-40), which can survive pressures up to 8 MPa. Combined with DFT calculations, we’ve found that the ligands adopting a specific conformation and packing without π···π interactions are the reasons for its rigidified blue emission.
elements.clean_text: The conformation, packing mode, and blue fluorescence of a soft piezofluorochromic compound can be preserved by structurally fixing it into a solid calcium metal-organic framework (Ca-MOF, LIFM-40), which can survive pressures up to 8 MPa. Combined with DFT calculations, we've found that the ligands adopting a specific conformation and packing without π⋅⋅⋅π interactions are the reasons for its rigidified blue emission.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a type of inorganic–organic hybrid material developing fast in the past few decades, showing great application potential in gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, liquid phase separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and other areas. The combinations of metal clusters and organic ligands result in highly crystalline frameworks, some of which can even maintain their structures and properties under harsh physical and chemical conditions. In this context, solid MOFs have shown their ability in controlling certain conformations of the organic ligand, such as restricting the phenyl ring rotations or rigidifying the ligand into a highly strained conformation. Then it was interesting to find out how far a MOF can go to restrict soft organic molecules whose properties are correlated with their conformations and packing modes.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a type of inorganic-organic hybrid material developing fast in the past few decades, showing great application potential in gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, liquid phase separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and other areas. The combinations of metal clusters and organic ligands result in highly crystalline frameworks, some of which can even maintain their structures and properties under harsh physical and chemical conditions. In this context, solid MOFs have shown their ability in controlling certain conformations of the organic ligand, such as restricting the phenyl ring rotations or rigidifying the ligand into a highly strained conformation. Then it was interesting to find out how far a MOF can go to restrict soft organic molecules whose properties are correlated with their conformations and packing modes.

elements.content: Piezofluorochromic materials can change their photoluminescence (PL) in response to mechanical stimuli. They are of practical importance for applications in mechanosensors, luminescence switches, security papers, and data storage. On the contrary, it is also a challenge to keep the specific luminescence of the piezofluorochromic materials unchanged since they are quite sensitive to the applied pressure. Since organic piezofluorochromic materials usually change their fluorescence upon changing of the conformations and packing modes, applying metal–organic coordination to restrict these parameters may be an effective strategy to control their fluorescence to manifest the MOFs’ rigidifying effect.
elements.clean_text: Piezofluorochromic materials can change their photoluminescence (PL) in response to mechanical stimuli. They are of practical importance for applications in mechanosensors, luminescence switches, security papers, and data storage. On the contrary, it is also a challenge to keep the specific luminescence of the piezofluorochromic materials unchanged since they are quite sensitive to the applied pressure. Since organic piezofluorochromic materials usually change their fluorescence upon changing of the conformations and packing modes, applying metal-organic coordination to restrict these parameters may be an effective strategy to control their fluorescence to manifest the MOFs' rigidifying effect.

elements.content: 4,4′-((Z,Z)-1,4-Diphenylbuta-1,3-diene-1,4-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (TABD–COOH) has been reported as a piezofluorochromic material. Its crystal emits blue fluorescence and is called the F-form. Under gentle grinding, the crystals will become powder to give out green fluorescence, and this is named the G-form. The molecules are packed orderly without forming π···π interactions in the F-form, while they are packed disorderly in the G-form with forming π···π interactions, and the changes in the molecular packing states account for the switches of its fluorescence. This sensitive molecule bares two carboxylate groups and can be easily rigidified into a solid MOF structure as a ligand. Then, the resulted MOF may have constrained conformation and packing states for the ligand molecules as well as protect them against mechano-stimuli.
elements.clean_text: 4,4'-((Z,Z)-1,4-Diphenylbuta-1,3-diene-1,4-diyl)dibenzoic acid (TABD-COOH) has been reported as a piezofluorochromic material. Its crystal emits blue fluorescence and is called the F-form. Under gentle grinding, the crystals will become powder to give out green fluorescence, and this is named the G-form. The molecules are packed orderly without forming π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the F-form, while they are packed disorderly in the G-form with forming π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, and the changes in the molecular packing states account for the switches of its fluorescence. This sensitive molecule bares two carboxylate groups and can be easily rigidified into a solid MOF structure as a ligand. Then, the resulted MOF may have constrained conformation and packing states for the ligand molecules as well as protect them against mechano-stimuli.

elements.content: Herein, we designed and synthesized a solid fluorescent calcium MOF {[Ca­(TABD-COO)­(DMF)2] n ; DMF means N,N-dimethylformamide} named LIFM-40 (LIFM stands for “Lehn Institute of Functional Materials”) from CaCl2 and TABD–COOH. As a cheap and abundant ion source, Ca­(II) with closed-shell electronic configuration is suitable for building luminescent MOFs with characteristics of ligand emission. LIFM-40 can sustain compression up to 8 MPa while maintaining its bright blue fluorescence. DFT calculations combining with experimental results have been used to confirm that the fixed ligand conformation and packing mode is responsible for the blue fluorescence.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we designed and synthesized a solid fluorescent calcium MOF {[Ca(TABD-COO)(DMF)2] n ; DMF means N,N-dimethylformamide} named LIFM-40 (LIFM stands for "Lehn Institute of Functional Materials") from CaCl2 and TABD-COOH. As a cheap and abundant ion source, Ca(II) with closed-shell electronic configuration is suitable for building luminescent MOFs with characteristics of ligand emission. LIFM-40 can sustain compression up to 8 MPa while maintaining its bright blue fluorescence. DFT calculations combining with experimental results have been used to confirm that the fixed ligand conformation and packing mode is responsible for the blue fluorescence.

elements.content: LIFM-40 was synthesized as colorless crystals by a solvothermal reaction between TABD-COOH and CaCl2 in DMF with trifluoracetic acid at 100 °C for 2 days. A single-crystal diffraction study revealed that LIFM-40 is crystallized in orthorhombic space group, P212121. The crystal is racemic twinning. There is a 21 axis along the c axis direction. The TABD-COO2– ligand keeps its trans conformation just as TABD-COOH (a). The two CC bonds formed a conjugated delocalized system. The two phenyl rings with carboxylate groups are parallel to each other while the other two phenyl rings are parallel to each other. Each oxygen atom of the ligand connects one Ca­(II), respectively. Then, every ligand connects four Ca­(II) cations. Every Ca­(II) cation is six-coordinated by two DMF molecules in axial positions and four oxygens coming from four TABD-COO2– linkers in equatorial positions (b). All Ca­(II) octahedra are linked through bridging carboxylate groups to form infinite chains along the b axis (b). These chains are further connected by the TABD-COO2– linkers to produce a 3D framework (c). If the Ca­(II) octahedra and TABD-COO2– are both viewed as 4-connecting nodes, the framework can be simplified as a 4-c uninodal net with lvt topology (d).
elements.clean_text: LIFM-40 was synthesized as colorless crystals by a solvothermal reaction between TABD-COOH and CaCl2 in DMF with trifluoracetic acid at 100 °C for 2 days. A single-crystal diffraction study revealed that LIFM-40 is crystallized in orthorhombic space group, P212121. The crystal is racemic twinning. There is a 21 axis along the c axis direction. The TABD-COO2- ligand keeps its trans conformation just as TABD-COOH (a). The two CC bonds formed a conjugated delocalized system. The two phenyl rings with carboxylate groups are parallel to each other while the other two phenyl rings are parallel to each other. Each oxygen atom of the ligand connects one Ca(II), respectively. Then, every ligand connects four Ca(II) cations. Every Ca(II) cation is six-coordinated by two DMF molecules in axial positions and four oxygens coming from four TABD-COO2- linkers in equatorial positions (b). All Ca(II) octahedra are linked through bridging carboxylate groups to form infinite chains along the b axis (b). These chains are further connected by the TABD-COO2- linkers to produce a 3D framework (c). If the Ca(II) octahedra and TABD-COO2- are both viewed as 4-connecting nodes, the framework can be simplified as a 4-c uninodal net with  lvt  topology (d).

elements.content: (a) The conformation of TABD-COO2– in LIFM-40. (b) The CaO x chain. (c) Viewing of LIFM-40 along the b axis. (d) The topology of LIFM-40. Color scheme: black, C; blue, N; red, O; white, H; green octahedral, Ca; aqua square, 4-connecting nodes; orange box, unit cell.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The conformation of TABD-COO2- in LIFM-40. (b) The CaO x  chain. (c) Viewing of LIFM-40 along the b axis. (d) The topology of LIFM-40. Color scheme: black, C; blue, N; red, O; white, H; green octahedral, Ca; aqua square, 4-connecting nodes; orange box, unit cell.

elements.content: The as-synthesized LIFM-40 crystals were washed twice with DMF and acetone, respectively, and then dried under air. The simply washed MOF sample is named as a fresh sample. The purity of the fresh MOF sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD, Figure S1a). The UV–vis absorption spectra shows that the TABD-COOH F-form has a broad absorption band expanding from 250 to 600 nm with maxima at 386 nm while LIFM-40 exhibits a sharper absorption profile extending between 330 and 500 nm with maxima at 410 nm, which is 24 nm red-shifted compare to the ligand absorption. PL measurements showed that the emission maximum of LIFM-40 is 444 nm, which is quite close to that of the TABD-COOH F-form (446 nm), suggesting that the MOF fluorescence is a ligand-based emission. Despite some differences, fluorescent emission curves and the color of LIFM-40 and F-form TABD-COOH are quite similar (a and Figures S1 and S2, see ). The lifetime of LIFM-40 was measured as 2.98 ns, confirming this photoluminescence is fluorescence. The quantum yield (Φ) of LIFM-40 reached 57 ± 3%, which is comparable to the that of TABD-COOH F-form (70 ± 3%) and much higher than other reported TABD-MOFs. The 57% quantum yield is also among the highest values for fluorescent MOFs. Therefore, the photos and measurements both proved that LIFM-40 has successfully locked a bright blue emission ligand in the framework.
elements.clean_text: The as-synthesized LIFM-40 crystals were washed twice with DMF and acetone, respectively, and then dried under air. The simply washed MOF sample is named as a fresh sample. The purity of the fresh MOF sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD, Figure S1a). The UV-vis absorption spectra shows that the TABD-COOH F-form has a broad absorption band expanding from 250 to 600 nm with maxima at 386 nm while LIFM-40 exhibits a sharper absorption profile extending between 330 and 500 nm with maxima at 410 nm, which is 24 nm red-shifted compare to the ligand absorption. PL measurements showed that the emission maximum of LIFM-40 is 444 nm, which is quite close to that of the TABD-COOH F-form (446 nm), suggesting that the MOF fluorescence is a ligand-based emission. Despite some differences, fluorescent emission curves and the color of LIFM-40 and F-form TABD-COOH are quite similar (a and Figures S1 and S2, see ). The lifetime of LIFM-40 was measured as 2.98 ns, confirming this photoluminescence is fluorescence. The quantum yield (Φ) of LIFM-40 reached 57 ± 3%, which is comparable to the that of TABD-COOH F-form (70 ± 3%) and much higher than other reported TABD-MOFs. The 57% quantum yield is also among the highest values for fluorescent MOFs. Therefore, the photos and measurements both proved that LIFM-40 has successfully locked a bright blue emission ligand in the framework.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescent emission spectra of LIFM-40 samples and TABD-COOH samples. (b) The overlap of the optimized TABD-COOH conformations in the F-form crystal (blue) and LIFM-40 (red), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Fluorescent emission spectra of LIFM-40 samples and TABD-COOH samples. (b) The overlap of the optimized TABD-COOH conformations in the F-form crystal (blue) and LIFM-40 (red), respectively.

elements.content: The rigidity of the LIFM-40 was examined by compressing it under different pressures. First, crystals of LIFM-40 are ground by hand in a mortar. Then, the LIFM-40 samples from the same batch were compressed under different pressures ranging from 2 to 12 MPa. After the compression, PXRD, PL, and quantum yield measurements were performed. The PXRD patterns showed that the MOF structure keeps crystallinity until 8 MPa and starts to lose it under 10 MPa and lost most of it under 12 MPa. The PL measurements proved that the fluorescent emission of LIFM-40 is also preserved (a, ). The emission curves of LIFM-40 samples overlapped with each other very well and give out basically the same CIE coordinates. Even after being compressed by 12 MPa and losing crystallinity, LIFM-40 still preserved its blue fluorescence. However, the Φ of the LIFM-40 samples dropped from 57 ± 3% to 47 ± 3% step by step after compression under 2–8 MPa. And its Φ suddenly dropped to 35 ± 3% after compression under 10 MPa and kept unchanged under 12 MPa (). The data suggest that as the pressure increases, π···π interactions start to form to quench the fluorescence due to the structure distortion. Finally, the framework collapsed at 10 MPa, and the quantum yield dropped 20% compared to the fresh crystal, despite the PXRD pattern still showing weak peaks. Besides, more crystal defects introduced by grinding will also cause a quantum yield decrease. The results also showed that the quantum yield measurements of LIFM-40 are much more sensitive to the MOF structural changes than PXRD and PL measurements. These results confirmed that unlike the sensitive piezofluorochromic ligand, the solid LIFM-40 can maintain its overall structure and fluorescence under high pressures.
elements.clean_text: The rigidity of the LIFM-40 was examined by compressing it under different pressures. First, crystals of LIFM-40 are ground by hand in a mortar. Then, the LIFM-40 samples from the same batch were compressed under different pressures ranging from 2 to 12 MPa. After the compression, PXRD, PL, and quantum yield measurements were performed. The PXRD patterns showed that the MOF structure keeps crystallinity until 8 MPa and starts to lose it under 10 MPa and lost most of it under 12 MPa. The PL measurements proved that the fluorescent emission of LIFM-40 is also preserved (a, ). The emission curves of LIFM-40 samples overlapped with each other very well and give out basically the same CIE coordinates. Even after being compressed by 12 MPa and losing crystallinity, LIFM-40 still preserved its blue fluorescence. However, the Φ of the LIFM-40 samples dropped from 57 ± 3% to 47 ± 3% step by step after compression under 2-8 MPa. And its Φ suddenly dropped to 35 ± 3% after compression under 10 MPa and kept unchanged under 12 MPa (). The data suggest that as the pressure increases, π⋅⋅⋅π interactions start to form to quench the fluorescence due to the structure distortion. Finally, the framework collapsed at 10 MPa, and the quantum yield dropped 20% compared to the fresh crystal, despite the PXRD pattern still showing weak peaks. Besides, more crystal defects introduced by grinding will also cause a quantum yield decrease. The results also showed that the quantum yield measurements of LIFM-40 are much more sensitive to the MOF structural changes than PXRD and PL measurements. These results confirmed that unlike the sensitive piezofluorochromic ligand, the solid LIFM-40 can maintain its overall structure and fluorescence under high pressures.

elements.content:
Furthermore, the thermal stability of LIFM-40 was examined. The TGA curves and variable-temperature-dependent PXRD patterns showed that LIFM-40 starts to decompose at about 200 °C ().

DFT calculations have been performed to explain the similarity of the fluorescent emissions between TABD-COOH F-form and LIFM-40. First, the conformations of TABD-COOH in the F-from and LIFM-40 were compared. Despite small differences, the conformations of the TABD-COOH in the F-form and LIFM-40 are quite similar and can almost overlap with each other (b). Then, TD-DFT calculations have been performed to get simulated UV–vis spectra for both TABD-COOH conformations. The simulated UV–vis absorption curves are very similar based on similar conformations, except the F-form has a shoulder at 450 nm while LIFM-40 has a peak at 450 nm. This agreed with the experimental UV–vis spectra of the TABD-COOH F-form and LIFM-40 that they have a similar shape, while LIFM-40 has more absorption in the long wavelength region (). Furthermore, the smaller HOMO–LUMO gap of the LIFM-40 conformation is consistent with the experiment that LIFM-40’s UV–vis absorption is red-shifted compared to F-form’s absorption (). Hence, the similar conformations of TABD-COOH in the F-form crystal and LIFM-40 is one chief reason for the ligand-based fluorescent emission.
elements.clean_text:
Furthermore, the thermal stability of LIFM-40 was examined. The TGA curves and variable-temperature-dependent PXRD patterns showed that LIFM-40 starts to decompose at about 200 °C ().

DFT calculations have been performed to explain the similarity of the fluorescent emissions between TABD-COOH F-form and LIFM-40. First, the conformations of TABD-COOH in the F-from and LIFM-40 were compared. Despite small differences, the conformations of the TABD-COOH in the F-form and LIFM-40 are quite similar and can almost overlap with each other (b). Then, TD-DFT calculations have been performed to get simulated UV-vis spectra for both TABD-COOH conformations. The simulated UV-vis absorption curves are very similar based on similar conformations, except the F-form has a shoulder at 450 nm while LIFM-40 has a peak at 450 nm. This agreed with the experimental UV-vis spectra of the TABD-COOH F-form and LIFM-40 that they have a similar shape, while LIFM-40 has more absorption in the long wavelength region (). Furthermore, the smaller HOMO-LUMO gap of the LIFM-40 conformation is consistent with the experiment that LIFM-40's UV-vis absorption is red-shifted compared to F-form's absorption (). Hence, the similar conformations of TABD-COOH in the F-form crystal and LIFM-40 is one chief reason for the ligand-based fluorescent emission.

elements.content: The second reason for the similar blue fluorescence is that both of their packing modes prohibit π···π interactions. In LIFM-40, there is no stacking of phenyl rings and no π···π interactions. It has only two types of C–H···π interactions with distances of 2.82 and 2.87 Å, respectively (). Similar to TABD-COOH F-form, these C–H···π interactions help constrain the rotation of phenyl rings and prohibit π···π interactions. Moreover, the rigidity of the solid framework protects this packing mode against compression up to 8 MPa. So no π···π interactions will form to change the band gap and fluorescence, which will happen in the ground TABD-COOH G-form.
elements.clean_text: The second reason for the similar blue fluorescence is that both of their packing modes prohibit π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. In LIFM-40, there is no stacking of phenyl rings and no π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. It has only two types of C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions with distances of 2.82 and 2.87 Å, respectively (). Similar to TABD-COOH F-form, these C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions help constrain the rotation of phenyl rings and prohibit π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Moreover, the rigidity of the solid framework protects this packing mode against compression up to 8 MPa. So no π⋅⋅⋅π interactions will form to change the band gap and fluorescence, which will happen in the ground TABD-COOH G-form.

elements.content: In summary, a piezofluorochromic ligand, TABD-COOH, has been structurally rigidified into a calcium MOF, LIFM-40, while still emits blue light as the ligand crystal and has a quantum yield reaching up to 57 ± 3%. The solid framework maintains its blue fluorescence under compression up to 8 MPa. The blue fluorescence mainly comes from its ligand conformation and no-π···π-interaction packing modes. Therefore, we have successfully demonstrated that MOF can restrict organic ligands into a specific conformation and packing modes to control their PL properties and protect them under high pressures.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a piezofluorochromic ligand, TABD-COOH, has been structurally rigidified into a calcium MOF, LIFM-40, while still emits blue light as the ligand crystal and has a quantum yield reaching up to 57 ± 3%. The solid framework maintains its blue fluorescence under compression up to 8 MPa. The blue fluorescence mainly comes from its ligand conformation and no-π⋅⋅⋅π-interaction packing modes. Therefore, we have successfully demonstrated that MOF can restrict organic ligands into a specific conformation and packing modes to control their PL properties and protect them under high pressures.

metadata.title:
Rigidifying Effect of Metal–Organic Frameworks:
Protect the Conformation, Packing Mode, and Blue Fluorescence of a
Soft Piezofluorochromic Compound under Pressures up to 8 MPa
